comments.commentBody: This is a wonderful story and I look forward to the next chapter.

A Columbia guy here who is always rooting for the Ivy teams, despite knowing they usually don't have a chance.  I think you guys are as good as Princeton's '98 team.  Great win today, congrats.  You made all Ivy Leaguers proud!  Beat Wisconsin!
It was not an upset.  Merely the better team won.  EOM.
Thamel is right: this is WV's year. They may be the 'cardiac kids' -- with their slow game starts and last minute wins -- but Huggins has a powerful team.

Adamar is a good basic hotel. Everything works. Breakfast terrace is very fine. From there you can watch the Bosborus and Asian side on Istanbul. Breakfast starts at 7 o´clock but is never ready. Staff takes care of their own breakfast first. If you want to eat the whole variety, it´s better to come later (7.40-).

Location is super. All major sights are round the corner. Lots of restaurants are close to the hotel and near tram stop. We were very satisfied with restaurants near tram stop. Food value was good.restaurant 100 meters uphill from the hotel is terrible and very expensive. Ask the price of every item before order.

Please, please, please don't do any elephant trekking. The elephants are generally not treated very well and the only way to stop it is to take the money out of it. We volunteered at a sanctuary for former logging/trekking/begging elephants near Chiang Mai, and the stories are heartbreaking. I can't believe the author recommended a gibbon sanctuary followed by elephant trekking. Ridiculous.

My son Jeremy was killed in Afghanistan on Jan. 23rd. He was 22 years old. He was a Marine, a son, a brother, a friend. He left his bedroom, his home, his life with every intention of returning to it. He was a smart, funny, brave young man. Young men just like him are being killed every day. People don't want to see images of combat zones. They don't want to see the images of flag draped coffins in Dover. We are still at war. My son gave his life for this war, this country...what do I do with his bedroom?
Just to clarify, I was referring to Ingrid K. Johnson's "36 Hours in Phuket" article of 3/19/10. She recommended a gibbon sanctuary followed by a horrifyingly exploitative elephant trek.

Oh, Irene #10, you’re being too flip and harsh about Mark #4. Of course, one does not have to be an addiction specialist to imagine or recognize certain classic addictive behaviors in David. His seduction of Jonathan to the point that Jonathan’s father, the king, called him David’s “bitch” (in the original). The grotesquely homoerotic lament when he was forever cut off from access to Jonathan.

The hundreds of sex toys in his harem indeed can suggest an addict’s development of, say, tolerance, having to increase the supply when the former supply ceases to trigger the former level of stimulation, endlessly dabbling in and moving on to variant supply to recapture declining thrill. And don’t neglect the mood swings in the Psalms, from ecstasy and bliss to melancholia on to utmost despair and vice versa -- a sex addict’s clinical roadmap.

Now, shall we have tea? Some of those little paper thin ginger cookies, please.

My son, now 11, started arm and head tics about 2 years ago. Suddenly and without warning. Prior to that he had behavioral issues. The tics got so bad in only a day and became full body tics. A neurologist gave him antibiotics saying it was caused by a strep infection. He didn't use the term pandas. Throughout the past 2 years they have reoccured a few times. Each time I would take him to his pediatrician and tell her to check for strep, she did, it was positive, antibiotics cured the tics. Now he has them again but this time VERY bad to the point where he cried at night because he couldn't fall asleep. In the meantime he was diagnosed with PANDAS but at the same time a psychiatrist diagnosed him with mental issues and put him on 3 meds. He now has a PANDAS doctor who has him on antibiotics. The problem, which medications are working on his behavior or not? This is an issue. But the point, PANDAS is real and the fact that the antibiotics clears it each time shows me it is. But apparently not for good.

I'm convinced my son has issues with PANDAS. When he was 2 or 3, he would regularly have tics. Twice he was hospitalized overnight for EEGs and other tests, which were negative. Over the past few years, the tics have largely gone away. However, every now and then the tics come back, we take him to the doctor, and strep is usually diagnosed. The tics come before the sore throat and fever....

Anyway, the "P" in PANDAS is for "pediatric". Does this mean the condition goes away at adulthood? Or does it just become less noticeable or more manageable?

Seventeen years ago, my seven year old started saving everything: old tissues, her toenails. She'd weep profusely if we threw away the wrappers from candy bars. It came out of nowhere, and we were terrified.

One therapist said it would take years of therapy to cure her. Another said, just go with it, and maybe it will pass. Help her save and she'll start saving less. Thank God for her calm advice. This quirkiness certainly did lessen, but the symptoms remained for a few years to a lesser degree.

Two years ago, when my daughter was 22, she read about PANDAS, and said, "That was me when I was little." And it certainly was! Every detail. Right down to the fact that she had scarlet fever right before it began. Of course, back then, no one understood the connection.

My daughter is now a healthy 24 year old who hardly saves a thing. What a relief! And I'm so happy for today's parents that there's a diagnosis for what terrified us back then.

As an infectious disease physician, I'm pleased to see the comment from Drs King and Leckman acknowledging the harms that come from indiscriminate antimicrobial use. However, I'm surprised to see this comment immediately afterwards: "(antibiotics) should be reserved for cases where there is clear-cut and convincing evidence that the onset or recurrent flare-up of tics/O.C.D. is linked to strep infection."

As I assume they are aware, the data for antibiotics in strep throat are marginal, at best. The guidelines from many countries (the UK, Canada, and others) advise not routinely treating with antibiotics, as the benefits are so miniscule. The specific complication of Rheumatic fever is so rare (outside of known local ourbreaks) that a Scottish study estimated 12 practitioners would have to treat all cases of strep throat for their entire careers to prevent one case. Sydenham’s chorea (postulated above to be a simialr related movement/tic disorder) is an even more rare complication of an already rare entity, and so would be even harder to prevent,

Thus, any endorsement of antibiotic treatment should be qualified that there is absolutely no evidence that it will work (as Ms Rae's comment #3 gives anecdotal support to). The 2nd commentator (steinbej) is completely correct- in the absence of data, these statements endorsing antibiotics are indeed breathtaking. And now they are given the platform of the most influential newspaper in the country. Not a good day for rational medicine.

To Steinbej (comment #2)
Your quote is from a Question, not an Answer, in the Qs and As in the article, and is thus not intended to be a "fact."

Am I missing something, or is this another case of many in the medical profession playing ostrich and arrogantly dismissing the observations of patients when new evidence comes along?

I'm as concerned as the next guy with the overuse of antibiotics, but waiting to treat seriously ill children until their is positive evidence that at the current state of the art is never likely to exist when we waste most antibiotics fattening food animals and many doctors continue to prescribe antibiotics for viral infections to keep the patient happy or because they don't want to bother with the appropriate test seems to me a serious case of misguided priorities.
In grade school a friend of mine was making a presentation before the class when he suddenly began skipping to the left and went out the doorway and collapsed in the hallway.

On the other hand, my younger daughter had strep three or four times a year in her first five years, then only two or three times a year until she turned 12. No tics, no OCD.

She also had pneumonia several times a year, and bronchitis--oh, the list goes on! We did eventually discover she had a genetic disorder that reduced her immune system. Her immune system gradually developed, so after age 12 she was ill no more often than anyone else.

The first sign of scarlet fever is obsessive hand washing, hours before the rash; Tourette’s is in the strep/O.C.D. family, or Panda. Why don’t they treat it with I.V. antibiotics and probiotics?
Bethany Brinton, Salt Lake City

I read this, and wondered where this lady came up with this information. The first sign? I don't think so. If you read the responses, in the article, by the experts, you'll note even they recognize PANDAS is not a common or easily recognized syndrome (syndrome, not a disease). In thirty years of practice, in a community with a very high rate of strept throat, I've never had a patient present with these symptoms (and yes, I would have noticed). Then we get to post number 6, totally off topic and off base.

The internet is wonderful, allowing anyone to learn about anything. Unfortunately, there are no rails to hang on to, maps on the floor to guide you.

I am a practicing pediatrician and admit to thorough confusion in regard to the PANDAS syndrome. It has all the ingredient of fuzzy science. First comes the question what is a streptococcal infection. Many positive throat cultures just signify a simple carrier state and not a genuine infection. Antibody titers are not always of help as most fall into a grey category. Normal values for ASO titers in different labs are different ( 50 to 150 I have seen). Then come the detractors: one must do more sophisticated subcategories of anti-streptococcal tests to prove or disprove; but those, on the other hand, are poorly normalized. No controlled studies and patients that suffer from stressful disorders: unfortunately this is a combination that leads to rigid belief. systems about treatments. I treat any sudden (sudden!) onset tic or anxiety with a long course of penicillin. That seems to be a decent middle course as of this time.
Karl Berger M. D.

To #2: I think the interview makes pretty clear that there is not much cohesive evidence on Pandas, or even much agreement among doctors that it exists, and that much of our experience regarding it is anecdotal.  But if a child is showing severe neuropsychiatric symptoms, and there's even a faint possibility that the disorder is being caused by an easily treatable bacterial agent rather than a major, actual psychiatric disorder, wouldn't you at least look into it?  Wouldn't you at least try?  If you could possibly put a child through a course of antibiotic treatment instead of a lifetime of psychoactive medication?

I’m concerned by the number of dismissive comments to Megan’s statement. Whether we talk about sexual infidelity in terms of sex addiction, sin, or with labels such as “cad,” the impact of the behavior is damaging and far-reaching. I’ve spent a great many years reasoning my way to understand the dysfunction in my family. The love of my life—my Father—was a “sex addict.” Over the past 65 years as I’ve learned more about his behavior, I’ve come to understand some of my Mother’s negative behaviors. She held our family together but often drifted into long periods of silence. Learning more about the dynamics of our home during my childhood has allowed me—over time—to forgive my Mother for some of her “heavy-handed” behavior and my Father for his infidelity (to the entire family).
My particular experiences have made me keenly aware of the verse—“The sins of the father are visited upon the son.” For those of us who have dealt with infidelity, as we come to understand the weakness and need of the family member who was disloyal, we stand a far better chance of bringing the cycle of pain generated by the disloyalty to an end; otherwise, the “sins of the father are visited” and revisited upon other family members and friends. The disloyalty puts in place a cycle of distrust and dysfunction that can only be ended by forgiving the one who betrayed the family.

Excellent restaurant. Good value for money. Hygienic and extremely delicious. Prakash is THE restaurant for authentic Maharashtrian food, though some might find it a bit spicy. Misal, sabudana vada and aloo vada are the best dishes there.

- Rushabh Mehta

"Another Sadr City resident, Abu Ahmed Hassan, 50, called Mr. Chalabi 'beloved.' He said, 'The Americans hate him, the Jordanians arrested him. So he must be good.'"

This is the image Chalabi needs to keep up; to be seen as supporter of the American invasion is a kiss of death politically. Why would an Iraqi support the invasion anyway? Unless he was part of the elite class that was shielded from the horrors of the war...oh wait...he is... So many innocent Iraqis dead; before there was one Sadaam, now there are thousands.

why don't you identify that the election system forced on Iraqis has nothing to do with true U.S. style "democracy", parliament is power by the party leaders, nothing else.

They face endless war until they modernize to more advanced election systems like IRV- IRv elects moderates with broad support, not violent extremists.

Despite the fact that Hurt is highly fictionalized ,I don't see much entertainment in that but more war propaganda favored by the DOD. More important is seeing Iraq as it is now with epidemic car bombs and suicide bombs and then comparing the conditions to Iraq before the invasion. The picture is telling ,especially from the aspect of US propaganda. Iraq was a stable thriving safe nation for most of it's citizens ,very similar to the US and Europe ,the persons with special interest connections received favor ,exactly as inn the USA. Sure Iraq had a few wars ,what nation hasn't ,yet Iraq was not an enemy of the US infact it was most predominatelyour business partner in the contacts of oil . Stressing the point Iraq was a safe thriving international business hub prior to the invasion ,Hurt Locker shows what it is like now.
